text: These verse segments are allegedly written by Yakov during his year on the Volga; they come divided in sections according to the time of the year, which is however never a specific season but a period between seasons. In this third section of Notes, the setting is late spring to late summer. The title of this chapter alludes to the portion of Mikhail Lermontov's 1839 novel *A Hero of Our Time* titled "Pechorin's Journal." Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/12/p.4/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/913/pg913-images.html).
Sparrow. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9b/House_sparrow_male_in_Prospect_Park_%2853532%29.jpg) Animal motif.

Sparrow Night — a short summer night with thunderstorms and lightning that frighten sparrows. The flashes of light on the dark sky are also said to resemble the birds themselves. Associated in folklore with evil spirits. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f9/Lightning_in_Volgograd_002.jpg) The first mention of Sparrow Night appears in the Primary Chronicle's account of the battle between the brothers Yaroslav the Wise and Mstislav in 1024. Read the original [here](http://www.spsl.nsc.ru/history/descr/PWL/povest3.htm) and an English translation [here](https://www.mgh-bibliothek.de/dokumente/a/a011458.pdf). Animal motif. The poem is structured as a long list of tools and animals, as if they appeared one after the other as lightning illuminated them during the night.
Sparrow. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9b/House_sparrow_male_in_Prospect_Park_%2853532%29.jpg) Animal motif.

Ilya is missing a leg.

As Boguslawski notes, this refers to "Arthur Rimbaud's unfinished collection of prose poems *Les Illuminations*, written between 1873 and 1875 and published first in 1886 ("Annotations" 254). The indeterminate nature of this work (prose poems) is apposite given the nature of *Between Dog and Wolf*.
During the Sparrow Night storm, the poet describes the sights and smell of lightning.

Similar to the title of chapter 3: Notes of a Binging Hunter. A distorted reference to Ivan Turgenev's 1852 cycle of short stories *Notes of a Hunter* (also translated as *A Sportsman's Notebook*, *The Hunting Sketches*, and *Sketches from a Hunter's Album*). This work was acclaimed for its portrayal of peasant life. The "Notes" (Записки) trope is common in Russian literature: *Notes of a Rifle Hunter* (Aksakov), Notes of a Shallow Grass (Dryansky), "Notes of a Madman" (Gogol), *Notes from the Underground* (Dostoevsky), *Notes from a Dead House* (Dostoevsky), "Notes of a Madman" (Tolstoy), "Notes of a Christian" (Tolstoy), *Notes of a Doctor* (Veresaev), *Notes of a Young Doctor* (Bulgakov), *Notes of a Psychotic* (Ven. Erofeev), and *Notes of a Nonhunter* (Vantalov).

text: Elena Kravchenko draws a parallel between Bruegel and William Carlos Williams's *[Pictures from Bruegel](https://www.fadedpage.com/books/20191144/html.php)* here: "On the macro-level, the body of the verse section forms a circular arrangement, based on the annual cycle, examined earlier in the chapter. While on the micro-level of individual poems the movement of eternal return is created through a 'shaggy dog tale' structure. This technique harks back to another ekphrastic evocation of Brueghel. William Carlos Williams wrote a cycle of poems, entitled Pictures from Brueghel (1962), wherein each poem represents an ekphrasis of a Brueghel painting. In his ekphrasis Williams reconstructs the outline of Brueghel’s paintings, as if following the viewer's eye in motion. Sokolov's homage to Brueghel's pictorial technique conceals reflections of/on Williams's representation of Brueghel, in which figures 'Disciplined by the artist | to go round | & round'. Adopting the manner of a 'shaggy dog tale', many of Iakov’s poems indeed go round and round" (*Reflections* 64).

text: Colloquial: someone who likes to party, relax, drink. The frequent use of variations on the verb *gulyat'* is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: "была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая" (R220/E124). In her case, "гулена" means "party person," and "гулящая" is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships. Alcohol theme.

This poem consists of a series of epitaphs, or short statements on the deceased, for a number of characters from the novel. The implication, of course, is that on one level all these characters are and have been dead. This poem recalls Edgar Lee Masters's *Spoon River Anthology* (1915), a collection of poems that tells the stories of a large collection of fictional characters through their epitaphs. Read it [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/1280/pg1280-images.html).

A possible reference to the Polish town of [Bydgoszcz](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Bydgoszcz,+Poland/@53.1256871,18.0381824,11z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m6!3m5!1s0x47031386764ebd6f:0xe49ee48c4b65f30e!8m2!3d53.1234804!4d18.0084378!16zL20vMGp3enA), but also a misspelling of the village of Vidogoshchi by the Volga river, near Tver'. Bydgoszcz is located on a river, the Brda. According to a legend, the city was founded by the brothers Byd and Gost in a place they deemed perfect also thanks to this river. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead ("Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209).
Dated: village church together with a cemetery, clergy house, and adjacent buildings.

text: Colloquial: someone who likes to party, relax, drink. The frequent use of variations on the verb *gulyat'* is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: "была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая" (R220/E124). In her case, "гулена" means "party person," and "гулящая" is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships. Alcohol theme.

A short pastoral poem often featuring a dialogue between shepherds. Alexander Pushkin mentions the genre in his novel-in-verse *Eugene Onegin* in [chapter 3 stanza 2](http://www.poetry-classic.ru/3-2.html). Elena Kravchenko describes the poem's technique as follows: "The technique of the ‘Eclogue’ draws on the parodic tradition of cento, a verse
composition made up of famous lines selected from the works of the past. A collage of voices, disposed in a new form or order, cento functions as parodic defamiliarization, refracting the intentions of originals. In the ‘Eclogue’ it is achieved through the juxtaposition of ‘polar’ opposites such as Khlebnikov and Turgenev, whose discourses produce the most improbable dialogue, and through the superimposition of the sign onto the alleged referent. This principle is captured in the poem’s title, ‘Eclogue’. The genre of the eclogue suggests a poem written in a classical style on a pastoral subject. Trans-contextualizing a classical verse into his novel, Sokolov creates a comic clash between the poem’s claims at bucolic bliss and the novel’s setting that starkly communicates a picture of the post-war devastation of provincial Russia. As has been noted, in its evocation of the pastoral, Sokolov’s poem is not a parody of the classical genre per se, but of the endeavour to compare artistic discourse about reality with reality itself. Moreover, it is not a simple parody of the truth-searching, but a parody of a parody: Iakov’s undertaking to compare the discourse of cultural ‘authorities’ with the real world is conceptualized through the evocation of his ‘precursors’, Don Quixote and Emma Bovary" (*Reflections* 58).

text: Elena Kravchenko writes, "Ivan Turgenev wrote a highly laudatory critical review of Aksakov's book, which was later published as part of Turgenev's *Collection of Works*. Thus the last two lines of the quatrain can be taken quite literally as Aksakov's ducks indeed constitute an element of Turgenev's book" (*Reflections* 57).

A reference to Ivan Turgenev's 1852 cycle of short stories *Notes of a Hunter* (also translated as *A Sportsman's Notebook*, *The Hunting Sketches*, and *Sketches from a Hunter's Album*). This work was acclaimed for its portrayal of peasant life.

text: Gerald Smith identifies this word (meaning "later," not "because") as "a neat laying-bare of the *post hoc, ergo propter hoc* fallacy," also known simply as the post hoc fallacy ("The Verse" 324).

Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov's art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg).  Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

Bayan — a chromatic button accordion from Russia. It was developed in the early twentieth century and named after Boyan, a bard from *The Lay of Igor's Campaign*, an epic Old Russian poem. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/42/Jupiter_bayan_accordion.JPG)

text: Colloquial: haunts. Typically used in the expression "вернуться во свояси" (to return to one's homeland). Leona Toker writes: "without mentioning the word 'return' the apostrophic penultimate line implies that the speaker has turned rather than re-turned, to his native region, earlier familiar to him only from literature and art. This is, or ought to be, his birthplace, or rather the birthplace of the language whose natural vitality he reclaims from oblivion" ("Gamesman's Sketches" 354–365). Elena Kravchenko reads this word as an allusion to Velimir Khlebnikov's 1919 article of the same name (*Reflections* 57). Read the original [here](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%A1%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%8F%D1%81%D0%B8_(%D0%A5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2)).

A possible reference to Turgenev's famous "prose poem" *Russky iazyk* (Russian Language). Read the original and an English translation [here](https://russianuniverse.org/2016/06/20/the-russian-language/).

Smith described this Note as having a linear structure, when observed through its verb tenses: it opens in perfective past, then moves to imperfective past, then to the present, then to a perfective future, and finally to an eternal present (1987).

Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4e/Sagittarius_Astrological_Sign_at_the_Wisconsin_State_Capitol.jpg)  Gerald Smith reads this poem as a "requiem for the backwoods life on the Volga written from the point of view of an exile or emigre, who compares emigration with death and who is nostalgic for what he has left behind" ("The Verse" 331). text: Scorpio — astrological sign and constellation. October 23 to November 21. According to Greek mythology, Orion, the great hunter, sought to kill all animals, so the goddess Gaia ordered Scorpio, a giant scorpion, to kill him. Upon stinging him, Scorpio was raised to the heavens where he spends half the year chasing the hunter. Constellation-heavens motif.

Between dog and wolf. "Blinded" in the sense that it's difficult to make out what is before one's eyes during twilight.
Elena Kravchenko suggests that this poem is "[s]prinkled with Pushkinisms" and "reiterates the motifs of Nekrasov's 'Orina, mat' soldatskaia'" (*Reflections* 59).
A document issued in case of transportation of cash and other valuables. Here these Notes are considered valuables.
Colloquial: an unmarried, lonely (peasant) woman. She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.
